entry.title: Our Loss is the World's Gain
entry.content:
I wasn't sure when Tim was going public with this, but now everyone knows that Tim Ewald is leaving Microsoft.
 
I have to admit, that the news was a pretty big blow to me when he told me early in September.

Even though I saw it coming for months, it was still a shock that took me days to come to terms with.
 
It's really been a bittersweet event for me.
 
On the one hand, I hate to see someone leave "my tribe" and I obviously tried hard to get him to come to Indigo rather than leave MSFT entirely.  More importantly, the one-week-a-month visits from Tim will be missed by both me and my entire family (especially Evan).
 
On the other hand, it was the best week I'd spent with Tim in at least a year.
 
Despite the great success he had this last year (look here for evidence - we finally have permalinks that map to CLR metadata!), the frustrations of dealing with operations and org dynamics were getting worse every month.
 
Free from these frustrations, the old Tim was back during our week together and it was fantastic.
 
I hope that Mindreef gives him the environment he needs to be the Tim Ewald that the world needs him to be.
 
If not, I'll move heaven and earth to create one for him myself.
 
Good luck, my friend!

entry.title: .NET vs. Windows
entry.content:
Keith's book title, The .NET Developer's Guide to Windows Security, begs the obvious question (which comes up in the comments on his blog):
 
What's the difference between a Windows Developer and a .NET Developer?
 
To be clear,
 
  1. Windows is an operating system product sold by Microsoft that runs on more than 90% of the PCs on the planet.
  2. .NET is a technology from Microsoft that combines XML Web Services (for remote integration) and the CLR (for local integration and execution). The CLR is an implementation of the ECMA CLI spec that is tightly integrated with Windows.
 
In all likelihood, when you write C# code, your code also depends on assemblies that are part of the .NET Framework. Those assemblies (like the CLR itself) are designed and optimized to run on Windows, so in one sense, your writing Windows code. Despite the fact that there are clones of the .NET Framework that run on other platforms, unless you test against those configurations, the "write once run anywhere-ness" of your code is highly speculative IMO.
 
Of course, not all Windows developers are .NET developers (yet).
 
Hence Keith's title.
 
As for the relevance of the book, I for one think it's super important that developers understand how platform and network security impact managed code, which is the raison d'etre of Keith's book.
 
Of course, being Microsoft, we're going to complicate this analysis by introducing the WinFX term into the lexicon. :-)

entry.title: re: .NET vs. Windows
entry.content: I am sure it's not just our company or just the devs I associate with here in the UK but, for us, a windows developer works directly with the Win32 API (e.g. C++, MFC etc). VB devs are not windows devs they are..VB devs and .NET devs are...NET devs. Anybody else is a non-MSFT-tool developer. WinFX devs are still .NET devs so no new grouping there. Anyway, what's in a name?

entry.title: re: .NET vs. Windows
entry.content:
I remember in 2001, when I saw you at Conference.NET in San Francisco (August 13-15, 2001), when you were a DevelopMentor guy, I talked to Matt Pietrek about this topic. It's not made to be compared, on one side you have the old-guys with C skills and a lot of things inside and on the other side, most of time, you have people who have seen like a miracle every morning. They talk about .NET like they talk about Java. It's wonderfull, it's great, it's beautifull : OK !
But, in the company I used to work, (European Banks), .NET guys begin to code... and old-Win32-guys help them to solve the problems. Debugging is more difficult (in large scale multiple tiers applications) in the .NET world than in the Win32-Process-Library world.

My favorite guy (except U, Don) is Matt (Piettreck & Woodring) are the various columns talking about Debuggin& multithreading issues. Who in the .NET world need to worry about thoses king of hard-fun-fast-good techniques ? As a consultant (small part of my job), I read source code of various teams in various company, and its fun to explain them it's better to rely on big software rather let them code something which look like a poor server side code.

There are two worlds.
There two king of people.
There two cultures.

Some people, like you (and your friends like Chris Sells & co) can handle multiple technologies but most of the people I meet are so scraed about reading books and just the simplified API docs that It's not a good idea to let them code like I love to write under the Win32 world.

My vision is may be, too simple, but this is the vision I have meeting both community in France and UK.

entry.title: Windows开发人员与.Net开发人员的区别
.Net vs Windows
What I'm Reading
entry.content:
I'm currently reading (and loving) Robert Evans' The Kid Stays in the Picture.
 
Yes, I know the book is a decade old, but I loved the movie so much (and PVR Kid Notorious religiously), that I wanted more.  I've gotten so into the movie that in a recent slide review I told a PM whose talk didn't quite capture the expansiveness of his feature "Kid, you shot an epic but you turned in a trailer."  Of course, I haven't gotten so into it that I refer to myself as Box yet.
 
I've been hanging around with Keith Short enough that today he gave me a signed copy of his book, Software Factories.  I plan to read it front-to-back once I finish the Evans book this weekend.  Keith has built some extremely interesting stuff in VS.NET that doesn't ever come out in the "box and arrow" demos you see at any Whitehorse demo. I'm looking forward to spending more time with Keith and his odd but wonderful little modeling engine.
 
Another book I picked up today was Crupi's Core J2EE Patterns and just spent my first hour with it.  I have to admit it - the book leaves me puzzled. Not because it is poorly written (it's not) nor is the information in it bad (after an hour, I hadn't had a single "no, don't do that" moment). However, a lot of the advice seems pretty obvious and (more problematically for me) introduces concepts and/or nomenclature for stuff for little good reason (Business Object, Application Service).   I'm hoping that Ted Neward's Effective J2EE will speak to me more than the Crupi book.
 
Thankfully, my blog now has comments so the world at large can educate me on how ignorant or brutish I am.

entry.title: re: What I'm Reading
entry.content:
In defense of Core J2EE patterns, I bought the first edition in 2001 when I was a few months out of college and doing J2EE programming for IBM. I had not had much exposure to enterprise computing concepts in my computer science classes at Penn State (which were more focused on data structures, algorithms and discrete math) so reading this book provided a good introduction to the concepts and problems that I was running into on a daily basis but might not have understood nor have been able to name.

I bought the second edition last year and have probably only picked it up a couple of times because, like you said, many of the concepts once you know them are straightforward.

But I still work at IBM and I hear the names of the patterns used on a routine basis.

PS - I actually prefer Martin Fowler's "Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture" to this book, simply because it covers much of the same ground I like his informal style of writing.

entry.title: re: What I'm Reading
entry.content: One other follow-up. Are there any other books on patterns of enteprise application development (wether J2EE, .NET or whatever) that *you* would recommend?

entry.title: Neward on Crupi
The Five Minute Challenge
entry.content:
Today someone challenged me to explain Indigo in five minutes. 
 
Here goes.
 
Indigo connects software together using structural contracts (a.k.a. schemas) and behavioral contracts (a.k.a. message exchange patterns).
 
We integrate with the CLR and COM and eviscerate your local types into either data contracts or service contracts, but never both. An especially cool feature of Indigo is that the sender and receiver don't need to share the same CLR types (nor do both sides even need to be Indigo or CLR or COM).
 
The messages we use in Indigo are based on the SOAP processing/data model but don't use angle brackets unless we are forced to, and when forced to, we do it happily and pretty damn fast.
 
We support a variety of message transports and support both transport-level and SOAP-level security and reliability.
 
Oh yeah, and we integrate tightly with System.Transactions and a queueing system.
 
There. That took me less than five minutes and I type much slower than I speak.
 
Maybe I'm jaded, but I'm skeptical of technologies whose core concepts can't be explained crisply in five minutes or less.

entry.title: On Complexity
entry.content:
Christophe Pichaud has an interesting comment elsewhere on this blog regarding Matt Pietrek.
 
Matt's a friend who I dearly love and have tons of respect for.
 
That stated, I think that if the world needs to understand and/or code against the stuff that Matt understands, we're doomed.
 
Are algorithms and abstractions important? Damn straight!
 
Is design and architecture important? Duh.
 
If hundreds of thousands of developers are programming directly against the TIB or cracking COFF/PDB files for non-masturbatory purposes, we screwed up the platform big time.

entry.title: re: On Complexity
entry.content:
Actually, that original comment looked an awful lot like Real Programmerism..."Of course, people who know what they're doing don't bother with any of that girlie machine code nonsense, they get down there and direct the flow of electrons themselves".
I like tools that are abstraction-friendly because abstractions are closer to the actual problems we are trying to solve (the machine, the OS and the code are not ends in themselves)...and also of course they save me lots of time.
So let the Win32 bigots patronise me all they want, if it makes them happy. The sky is still blue (sometimes), good wine is still a joy to the palate and the soul, and pretty girls are still as pretty as always.
I value perspective :-)

entry.title: re: On Complexity
entry.content:
I think you're missing the point. If you've invested the better part of the last ten years becoming a Win32/MFC/C++ expert, it's a huge ego blow to become a novice again, and to have to re-learn how to do things.

Learning new APIs is something that some people are good at, and others struggle with. I don't think the win32 bigots are necessarily patronizing you, it's just that they fear the new and unknown.

The other thing to remember is that the high-level abstraction leaks implementation details, and will occasionally need to be debugged or worked around. That's when a low- level understanding is good to have. Otherwise you end up with cargo-cult programming: "The wizard gave me this code and it just works, but now the server has been changed and the code broke. Waah!"

entry.title: Tim and Michi
entry.content:
There's an interesting back and forth between Tim Ewald and Michi Henning over on Tim's blog.
 
Here's my 2 cents.
 
CORBA did some things extremely well. They started with a meta-model (IDL) and corresponding wire protocols (GIOP/IIOP). Good so far.
 
They even defined a few application protocols, although there were as many false starts (persistence, naming) as there were successes (trader).
 
The fact that security wasn't built in early didn't bode well, as it's hard to imagine building anything interesting without security. With SOAP, we bootstrapped off of SSL/TLS and implementations of a SOAP-specific mechanism (WS-Security) are coming slowly but surely.
 
For me, the fatal problem for CORBA was that they also tried to tackle standardizing programming models/language bindings. 
 
Ever use CORBA using the C++ language bindings? Yuck.
 
How about in Java - not so good either.
 
We made the same mistake when we tried to take DCOM to UNIX. We could have done a protocol-only approach and built on a UNIX-based DCE library, but instead, we brought along a programming model that was designed to the Windows esthetic, not the UNIX one.
 
Fortunately, we're not taking that approach this time and people can pick their local programming system as they (or their employers) see fit.  Our goal in Indigo is to make sure no developer is thinking about WS-*. Does this mean we're "hide the XML" guys - no.  XML is our untyped story throughout Indigo. It does mean that the wiring up of WS-Policy/Security/SecConv/Trust/RM/Coordination et al is handled by our plumbing and unless you want to monkey with those headers, you don't have to.
 
As for the WS-* stack, I'm actually getting increasingly interested in WS-ReliableMessaging. The ability to maintain an end-to-end ordered sequence that survives transport teardown/re-establishment is pretty useful if you're trying to do any kind of conversational work.  For the unordered idempotent stuff that Tim was doing before he left this Redmond coil, it's less of an interesting tool.

entry.title: re: Tim and Michi
entry.content:
Hi Don,

actually, standardizing the language mapping is a good idea, IMO. It gives me source-code portability, without which, I'd be at the mercy of each vendor's tool kit. I agree that the CORBA C++ mapping sucks. But that isn't in the nature of the beast. Ice amply demonstrates that -- its C++ mapping really flies. Easy, intuitive, no complexity, no leaks, and integrated with STL. So, there is nothing wrong with standardizing language mappings, but there is everything wrong with standardizing on a poor language mapping that is created without prior experience.

I think this really underscores the comments I made in Tim's blog: it takes us a few goes to get things right.

I agree with your comment on security also: not having security in something such as CORBA is almost the same as issuing the death certificate before the birth certificate...

Cheers,

Michi.

entry.title: More on the state of Web services...
Don on what CORBA got wrong
entry.content: Over in his new blog, Don comments on what he thinks CORBA got wrong. This might surprise you, but I wholly agree with him, and in fact I would state some of what he said even more strongly. Now, don't get me wrong -- I haven't turned into some sort of CORBA turncoat or traitor, spewing FUD about it like there's no tomorrow (like one guy I know). There is simply no denying that CORBA has succeeded wildly and remains a viable solution for problems requiring high-performance and flexible custom integration, nor is there any use in denying that the distributed computing world has advanced considerably due to CORBA. Rather, I think it's just generally useful to fairly and objectively analyze and criticize technologies so we can learn and improve. Specifically, I agree with Don about the programming model issue. We CORBA types have been saying for years that there's...

entry.title: Corba: not enough early focus on interop
entry.content:
One key early failing of CORBA was (IMO) it's lack of focus on interop; there may have been a standard API, but with a choice of Apollo or Sun wire formats from the outset meant you were doomed for interop.

The other is the language binding. The Corba bindings suffer from their age. I think DOM has the same flaw, and even COM IDL generates "legacy" C++ code, last time I looked. Maybe the issue is that languages aren't designed with the needs of high-longevity distributed systems in mind, and all attempts to make remote systems look like local objects are ultimately doomed. I think Erlang does it the best; its almost enough to make we want to use Corba again. But then I'd have to learn Erlang properly.

entry.title: re: Tim and Michi
entry.content: The *main* problem with CORBA was that you guys (MS that is) never bought in -- and obviously not because of technical reasons, but rather motivated by politics. Maybe MS has changed enough so that (in theory) things would be different in a similar situation now ...

entry.title: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
Ted chimes in on my puzzlement over Crupi.  I'm glad to hear that there isn't some deep insight that I'm missing.
 
One thing Ted mentions is the trend in the Java world towards things like Spring and PicoContainer. 
 
After perusing each site, I have a hard time seeing how Spring is any simpler than EJB.
 
The PicoContainer stuff was much more modest in its ambitions, but I'm not sure how much value their framework actually adds beyond the basic IoC idea (which I actually like a lot).
 
As an aside, I really wonder how many O/R mappers the world needs. It's frightening how much energy goes into building these things (on both sides of the aisle I might add).

entry.title: re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
Don--great to see you taking an interest in this stuff.

How is Spring simpler than EJB? I can't claim to give you an independent view, but given that I started from EJB and designed Spring with that experience in mind, I'm happy to compare the two. For a start, Spring (or any IoC + services framework) keeps the framework out of your code. That's a huge difference with many implications. Any object can be made transactional etc without that object needing to jump through hoops as with EJB. This is also great for reusing legacy code. The fact that there are less framework-specific requirements on objects means that you have greater freedom to practise OO.

Sure, you typically use some XML in Spring apps (although there are ways to minimize the amount of XML), but it's way less than you end up with with the EJB deployment descriptors.

Because your code isn't heavily dependent on the container, you can easily unit test it with something like JUnit. Huge productivity gain vs the cumbersome in-container testing strategies often seen in the past in J2EE. You can even run some integration tests using a Spring container but not a heavier J2EE app server--unlike any app server, a Spring container takes very little time to start up.

Compare the Spring Pet Store sample with a traditional EJB approach. In the Spring approach there's very little Java code that doesn't do anything...no service locators, JNDI lookup etc etc. In my experience from client projects, using a combination like Spring/Hibernate it's not unusual to end up with 10-20% of the code a traditional EJB-heavy J2EE app would have taken, with a significant gain in speed of delivery and maintainability.

My recent "J2EE without EJB" (Wrox Press), argues these points in much greater detail. But I'd love to discuss this with you, here or offline if you're interested.

Rgds
Rod

PS There's a .NET port of Pico and work is underway on one of Spring. (Strictly speaking it's not a "port" as that wouldn't make sense. The core IoC + AOP stuff is pretty similar, but when we get into the services the issues are different in .NET.)

entry.title: re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
This is great, I hope the thread continues...

Spring and PicoContainer both look great and there is a good .net implementation of PicoContainer, StructureMap (https://sourceforge.net/projects/structuremap/).

But it appears that .NET has a nice lightweight container implementation living in

Described in more detail by Kzu here: http://weblogs.asp.net/cazzu/archive/2004/05/10/129140.aspx

and by Brain Pepin here: http://www.urbanpotato.net/default.aspx/document/1757

Srdjan

entry.title: re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
Rod,

What I'm hearing you say is that EJB containers are too complicated and don't integrate well into test/debug infrastructure.

I'm not convinced that yet another layer is the answer to the former, and customers should hold EJB vendors (IBM, BEA) accountable for the latter.

BTW, I'm not bagging on your work - I'm just trying to grok the state of play in Java land.

Honestly, it appears to be absolute chaos to me (and I'm really not trying to FUD - I have plenty of chaos to deal with here in the big house).

DB

entry.title: re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
Don

In a high proportion of applications a "lightweight" container like Spring is not "yet another layer": you don't need the EJB infrastructure at all. It's a simpler layer that achieves most of the same ends, such as declarative tx mgt. Even where EJB is still useful (some remoting requirements etc.) an IoC container ends up replacing an in-house layer of software, rather than adding a layer that wouldn't otherwise have existed.

No argument that the standards/implementation should be simpler to use. J2EE hasn't done well there. The specs focus far to much on seldom-used high-end features, and forget the importance of making simple things simple. (I'm not too worried about this being quoted against me, as I've been saying it for over 2 years.) I believe that the better the design of an enterprise framework, the less complex the tool requirements should be for testing/debugging etc.

I don't agree that it's "chaos" in the Java world. I think that open source in particular has generated some great options, based on extensive experience in the field. It's taken a while, but now products like Hibernate and Spring have reached critical mass, so it's no longer necessary to do a lot of research to identify a suitable stack for say a transactional web app.

R

entry.title: re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
Don -

For me, the fact that technologies such as Spring and Hibernate are transparent is a huge win.

Also, you can add on services as you need to use them in your application.

With big frameworks like EJB you get the whole damn stack even though you don't want it.

http://www.almaer.com/blog/archives/000482.html

I brought this up at Tim Ewald's blog. Academically it was a very interesting discussion to follow. But even after the advent of O/R mappers like Hibernate (http://www.hibernate.org) which obviously has managed to garner a significant amount of mind-share among the Java developers, why don't the bigwigs of the industry consider the fact that Hibernate just might have got the approach right? Isn't the proof of the pudding in the eating?

entry.title: O/R Mappers - Take 2
re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
Have to agree with Dilip's comments, based on my practical observation. O/R mapping has produced a real productivity gain on a number of projects I've led.

Having said that, I believe that Java folk have traditionally been *too* eager to use O/R mapping. I don't hesitate to use a SQL-based approach where ORM is not a good fit.

In reference to Ted's comments, I think the "Vietnam" happens when you try to apply ORM where it doesn't fit, not in ORM per se. Shovelling an ORM where it doesn't belong gets nasty.

R

entry.title: re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content: +1 for Rod's latest book.

entry.title: re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
This is a really interesting time for Enterprise Java Development. We are finally seeing that the traditional EJB-centric applications and the excess of EJB "Design Pattern" overdose, dont work.
As a user of both Hibernate and Spring, I can personally attest to the fact that it is a much more productive environment.
Alot of the Core J2EE patterns are just not necessary. Why write/test/maintain code that has no business value? The plumbing should be provided transparently to us. EJB was supposed to let the developer focus on business logic..and provide the middleware services (?) If so, then why do we still see tonnes of Service Locator,Business Delegate, JNDI, etc.. ?

IoC, AOP (i.e. Spring) and transparent POJO persistence (i.e. Hibernate) have been extremely useful in the applications that I have been developing.
This isnt a blanket solution.. as it depends on the business requirements.
However for a great number of applications it can provide alot of value.

Also Eric Evans' DDD is a great book, as well as Fowler's PoEAA. These are the tech-agnostic books that really translate well to applications that actually embrace the OO in Java.

entry.title: re: Neward on Crupi
entry.content:
Don,

To play the "middle-ground" here, I'd say there is a great deal of chaos, and a good deal of order in the Java universe. (And in a way, chaos is a good thing, because it calls for evolution). In general I'd say we all agree:

"The J2EE APIs/Abstractions (as provided by Sun) have failed to provide a good development environment for solving business problems."

The core of the issue is "How the technology goes about solving the business problem". There are plenty of issues (validation, exception handling, job scheduling, transaction mgmt.) involved in solving "the problem", (some of these things are handled within the J2EE/ EJB 3.0 specs, some not).

This is the beauty of Spring, not just the ORM integration. J2EE provides many loosely coupled APIs, but where does that leave you?... You are still relatively "far away" from a "business solution". The abstractions provided by Sun (particularly JDBC) have failed, and hence ORMs are around to make developers lives easier... Which ORM to use?? well it depends on the application, here's where Spring shows off it's power)

Spring has a huge value add in the respect of being able to "pull together/harness" all of the J2EE APIs as well as Open source APIs/solutions/components under one umbrella. A developer doesn't need to learn too much about the Quartz Job Scheduler to integrate scheduling into thier application. They can refer to the Spring API (and examples), plug in the jar, and configure it in an XML file in a "way" that is familiar to them. If something better comes along for Job Scheduling, plug that jar in, update the configuration, and you are off to the races. (You aren't "bured" on having to spend weeks trying to develop, understand, and configure an API that becomes outdated). As technology evolves (i.e. these Chaotic ORM's), you don't need to go back to the drawing board and learn all of the nasty configuration details.

To summarize, IMO Spring is a "lightweight platform" and J2EE which is a library of API's, to focus on "how Spring directly compares with EJB3.0" may be missing the big "business" picture.

entry.title: Why Indigo? : The Five Minute Challenge
entry.content:
Miles Archer nailed me for not hitting the "why" in my Five Minute Challenge on Indigo.
 
I completely agree that the why is at least as important as the what, often way more important. 
 
So, here's why we did Indigo in five minutes or less:
 
Most software development is gluing together code that's already been built and/or information that's already been stored. Very few people have the luxury of doing pure green fields development.
 
The status quo for both Microsoft and the industry at large is to create a bunch of stovepipe solutions to integration (CORBA, DCOM, EDI) and access (JNDI, JDBC, JMX) and let the developers (or more likely, the consultants) sort it out. On Indigo, we think we can build out a new general-purpose platform based on services that interact using XML messaging.
 
The choice of messaging as the central metaphor is to force us to keep the focus of integration on the data being exchanged, not the technology used on either end of the pipe. It's proven to be a great discipline and has given a several hundred person team of a great focal point since the inception of Indigo.
 
The choice of XML was to make the bar of entry as low as possible. In retrospect, the XML stack has gotten so complex (XSD, XML DSIG, XML Encryption, XQuery) that I often wish we'd have based the architecture on Lisp S-Expressions instead of XML, but here we are.
 
The choice of the term "service" is actually kind of arbitrary. The industry as a whole needed a term for a piece of code that you interact with using XML messages, and service was the first term to stick. I'm sure once the glow on "SOA" has started to fade, we'll get pressure to use a different name (can you say "business agents"?).
 
The interesting question (in my mind) is why is Microsoft doing this at all?  It's easy. We needed a substrate for local execution to build out the new platform, so we built the CLR. That CLR-based platform needs a substrate for distributed/heterogeneous integration and access, so we're building Indigo.
 
Like the CLR, Indigo is really a means to an end, not an end unto itself. It's our job to get out of the way. Period.

entry.title: re: Why Indigo? : The Five Minute Challenge
entry.content:
>The choice of XML was to make the bar of entry as low as possible. In retrospect, the XML stack has gotten so complex (XSD, XML DSIG, XML Encryption, XQuery) that I often wish we'd have based the architecture on Lisp S-Expressions instead of XML, but here we are.

A lot of the complexity in the XML stack has little to do with the nature of angle brackets versus S-expressions. The complexity comes from people trying to use what was supposed to be "a better HTML" for every scenario under the sun. Such as being the cornerstone of a distributed coumputing protocol. ;)

I don't even know what have the specs are any more, because "The WS-GroceryOrdering spec was finalized this week!" has really become noise. I can't get my head around all of SOA with so many specs getting created, but it's a hell of a lot easier when there is a wrapper (Indigo) that just exposes them in terms of their atomic functions rather than breaking it up into who-knows-how-many-organizational-divisions and leave me to figure out what they all do and how I should integrate them; basically, I assume Indigo as a whole is complete enough for me to build a scalable app such that I don't have to read a myriad of specs to figure out how the thing can help me write code.

entry.title: What Indigo Is (and isn't)
re: Why Indigo? : The Five Minute Challenge
entry.content:
I am still struggling to find a compelling reason for WS and SOA. I can see that its great for interoperability across different platforms, and getting across the Internet by following the porn through port 80. (If WS is so compelling, it deserves its own set of ports, rather than having to piggy back http.)

The real problem with all this XML based technology is that its eating up processor and network bandwidth. What I really want COM+ and MSMQ services across the Internet, through routers and firewalls. (i.e. I want to be able to queue messages, event, and multicast notification messages across several hosts. I could do this SOA based design 5 years ago, with MS and J2EE technologies. Now I am seeing that I can now do it with WS, but a lot slower, because its XML.

As for XML, its great piece of information transfer technology. But why all the mass of technology. Surely it XML is just a tempory state of an object, that has been serialised, as part of it being a Data Transfer Object. I should be rebuilding it back into proper objects, so that I can rely upon compiler based validation and strong typing, and not validating at run time witrh expensive xsd processing. I could be using XSl, as a means to translate Objects from one class to another. Sure there are lots of other great pieces of XML technology, but lets keep it in proportion. We should be integrating it with good OO, Architecture and Design patterns stuff.

Still reading into WSE.

Jules

entry.title: EJB Backlash and Indigo
entry.content:
The Spring/PicoContainer discussion spurred on by Ted has been interesting to say the least.
 
I've spent some time thinking about whether we've taken adequate steps in Indigo to stem the need for dozens of alternative "containers."
 
Based on what I'm seeing, I think we're on a good path. Here're a few things that make me believe that:
 
  1. We don't mandate a process/appdomain host, so you can host Indigo services in any AppDomain or process you chose.
  2. Our dispatch and instancing pipeline is fully pluggable (and replacable) and is wired up to our metadata/contract engine.
  3. Most important data structures are extensible without resorting to subtyping.
 
Philosophically, we've done a good job at building simple and reliable mechanisms and not imposing a lot of policy on top.  This is similar to the approach taken by .NET Remoting (albeit in a somewhat different domain) and quite the opposite of the approach taken by MTS, COM+, and EJB.
 
I'd love to hear from the EJB alternative camp what they'd like to see from us in Indigo to keep them from reinventing the wheel over here in .NET land.
 
Thankfully, my blog now has comments :-)

entry.title: re: EJB Backlash and Indigo
entry.content:
Most EJB's guys I have spoken to still belive Web Service is a glorified RPC and continue along this path (and not document/literal). While reading your paper on Web Service Architecture on MSDN I though it would have been better when you invented SOAP called it SMAP (Simple Message Access Protocol)instead, :-) and we all would have been on the same plane.

Most EJB guys will whine about lack of JNS (Java Naming Service) and data persistance using XML (bad idea in my opinion). So far what I have seen of Indigo I like.

/Shaji

entry.title: re: EJB Backlash and Indigo
entry.content:
Shaji,

Thanks for the comments.

For one, the WSDL "doc/lit" setting is orthogonal to whether one programs or designs in terms of RPC.

Indigo always emits doc/lit as its external contract format, yet we support both "RPC" and "message" styles of local programming.

As far as not supporting naming, we wrestle with this one a lot.

On the one hand, our support for WS-Addressing and WS-MEX makes it pretty trivial for you to store EPRs pretty much anywhere you want and to search for them anyway you want.

On the other hand, people want a standard query mechanism to ask a store based on various criteria - the problem is no one agrees what that criteria should be (tModels anyone).

As for "data persistence using XML" we support serializing graphs of values as XML, but we don't support persistent objects that maintain identity a la Entity Beans. I for one hope we never do.

DB

entry.title: re: EJB Backlash and Indigo
entry.content:
BTW, the point of my query was not "what EJB features will people want in Indigo" but rather "what architectural choices/mistakes could we make that would foster dozens of 'mini-Indigos'" the way that EJB has fostered "mini-EJBs" like Spring (or to a lesser degree PicoContainter).

I assume that lack of modularity is mistake #1 - but I'm curious what specific pieces of EJB people really want to replace, remove, or extend that they can't with say WebSphere or even JBoss.

entry.title: re: EJB Backlash and Indigo
entry.content:
I've worked quite a bit with Pico and a few other IoC frameworks, e.g. Spring and Avalon, and I really think there are subtle nuances that differentiate them from Indigo, but overall they have a lot in common.

The primary use case for these IoC containers is for "near" situations; distributing components and services has always been a sort of afterthought for most of them. You've been pretty open about marketing Indigo as a "far" solution, with the caveat and hope that Indigo could be drawn closer to the finer-grained "near" situations. It’d be great to hear where Indigo is today, and how close you expect it to scale down to (it’s funny—usually we speak of scaling "up"...).

So with something like Pico, the primary concerns are setting up suitable "near" component interfaces while decoupling consumers with the specific implementation, configuration of individual components, controlling and injecting dependencies in a loosely coupled fashion (i.e. through configuration mechanisms), and monitoring the interactions between components (i.e. logging). The communication medium and contents of such communication is secondary, especially because many times this is all occurring within a closed system.

Indigo, on the other hand, is all about bringing diversity into the mix. That is, enabling an open ecosystem of software to agree on format and policy, and to communicate freely. Configuration, dependency management, and all of that goodness mentioned above are very important, but at a coarser-grained scale. It’s entirely reasonable to expect an Indigo service to be a layer on top of a container such as Pico, similar to how objects still matter underneath the messaging-goop layer. And in the same way you can’t just expose a bunch of fine-grained methods as endpoints (and expect to live, that is), opening up a component’s interface is likely not a good solution.

So I see an as-of-yet unmet need for an IoC solution in .NET (other than the straight OSS Java->C# ports that exist today). I’m sure Indigo could be tuned to handle these use cases (and IMHO it’d end up being quite nice: consistency in the way fine- and coarse-grained components are configured, etc), but this obviously hasn’t been the primary focus of the technology thus far...

<joe/>

entry.title: Bill de hOra On WS-Transfer
entry.content:
Of all of the blog activity around WS-Transfer, Bill's post wins my vote as the most insightful so far.
 
My favorite quote is the following:
 
Where WS-Transfer may prove useful is in breaking down barriers and getting architectural factions to the table by raising awareness that there are issues with both REST and Webservices approaches.
 
To me, this is the most important reason for shipping this particular spec. The fact that some people may implement it and get value from that implementation is pure gravy.
 
As an aside, I've always viewed SOAP as existing to put structure around POST and other "raw" message delivery metaphors. The motivation for using SOAP with HTTP GET has always been a stretch, as HTTP GET has well-enough defined semantics already (as the RESTafarians are so quick to point out).
 
And obviously, a big "+1" to the observation that the reality of HTTP (HEAD/GET/POST) is a far cry from Roy's post-mortem/thesis that captured people's imaginations.

entry.title: re: Bill de hOra On WS-Transfer
entry.content: Its surprising to see how equally competent people, experts in their fields pick on different points from the same post to focus on. f.e check out Steve Vinoski's latest entry.

entry.title: Still RESTless
Correcting MNot
entry.content:
OK, Mark, I'll take the bait accept your invitation and correct your very interesting entry on POST.
 
First, the use of PUT rather than POST was not a typo or slip up, but rather a deliberate statement.
 
In watching people (over)react to WS-Transfer, I've seen any number of examples where people model arbitrary operations as side-effects of PUT or DELETE.  I was trying to make that point in my original post. Sorry you misread it.
 
BTW, while I do claim that you can solve the majority of the world's problems using an arbitrary handful of operations, I never claim that actually requiring (or even recommending) the world to do so is a good idea.  It's a wonderful thought experiment, but trying to evangelize that the world only requires a fixed number of verbs is quite odd. 
 
Imagine if all Python (or Perl or Java or .NET) libraries all were required to implement only one interface. For example, imagine if the JDK had defined the following interface:
 
package java.lang;
 
public interface Object {
  object Create(object initData);
  object Get();
  void Put(object data);
  void Delete();
}
 
Now imagine every Java class implementing only this interface.
 
Could you build web apps? Sure. "Enterprise" or "Business" apps? Absolutely.  "Smart client" apps? I think I could do it.
 
To anticipate Patrick's comments, I'm a huge fan of minimal kernels of abstraction (like lisp) upon which we define entire universes. 
 
SOAP is minimalistic enough for me - it's sad (but not terminal) that SOAP's defun, WSDL/XSD, is as complicated as it is. 
 
Had we started with a simpler basis (perhaps Relax NG + some SOAP-specific extensions), my guess is we'd be having different discussions right now.

entry.title: re: Correcting MNot
entry.content:
Mmmmmm, bait...

If you really meant PUT, I agree with you on that point, although I must say that the SYSV runlevel example in the comments gives me pause. Do you consider that overloading?

WRT interface examples; just because specific interfaces makes sense in programming languages does not mean that they're good for distributed systems. I'm sure you're familiar with "A Note on Distributed Computing" (http://research.sun.com/techrep/1994/smli_tr-94-29.pdf), so I'm surprised to see you imply this.

Of course, that doesn't necessarily mean that uniform interfaces are better; just that arguing that they aren't desirable in programming languages isn't going to sway me much.

WRT Relax and SOAP - preaching to the choir. Tho I wonder if we'd get further with the RDF data model + RDF Schema (not the syntax, and not the higher levels of the semantic Web goo, at least yet). Of course, that's all moot now.

entry.title: re: Correcting MNot
entry.content:
Mark,

For one, I'm not swayed by the runlevel example. You should talk to the directory folks who've had to deal with this sort of action-via-side-effect for years. They hate it.

And yes, I'm familiar with the Waldo piece and largely agree with it. Note that in my example, I'm going the opposite direction, that is, taking an abstraction that has been held up as a "good" distributed abstraction and am using that as a thought experiment for in-process software design.

And btw, I actually think uniform interfaces in "local" programming languages are huge - look at what we've done with IEnumerator in C# (especially with yield return).

And of course, you know how I feel about Relax and RDF :-)

DB

entry.title: Coordination
entry.content:
Don, you wrote "It's a wonderful thought experiment, but trying to evangelize that the world only requires a fixed number of verbs is quite odd.". Not odd at all. It's how *all* Internet scale systems are built. Over the Internet, i.e. in multi-agency scenarios, integration is a coordination problem.

You can also look at this from a software architecture POV by simply examining the architectural properties induced by using a constrained interface. Things like visibility and simplicity. Without the constraint, you don't get those.

P.S. java.lang.Object already has Get() - it's called toString().

entry.title: re: Correcting MNot
entry.content:
As usual in debates over RESTifarianism, things quickly go off into the trees over fairly minor points (PUT vs POST in a hypothetical RESTful "reboot my computer" interface) and miss the forest (whether it makes sense to actually build real systems this way even if it is logically possible).

Don writes "It's a wonderful thought experiment, but trying to evangelize that the world only requires a fixed number of verbs is quite odd. " I agree -- all the pushback has been that it is *possible* to do anything with basically the CRUD operations (especially if you have an open ended "doStuff()" operator such as HTTP POST. Who is arguing that this actually makes practical engineering sense in concrete large-scale, mission-critical systems?

Just about every system I had much design input into when I was a hands-on software developer started with something like a CRUD API, and quickly added higher-complexity operations. It would be enlightening to hear from people who resisted this temptation and kept it simple .... and kept their jobs :-)

This reminds me of the C.J. Date and friends argument that SQL sucks because it doesn't implement the relational calculus and only the relational calculus. He's right that is is provably the case that one could build databases the pure relational way, but almost nobody does for large-scale applications. Ignorance, or practical solutions to inevitable tradeoffs in any engineering endeavor?

As I may have suggested to Mark Baker, once or twice, over the last few years, SHOW US!!! The Web doesn't count as an examnple because it the main service it provides *is* exchanging representations of information for human consumption. When we get into areas where machine integration is needed, REST tends to go out the window -- try using an e-commerce site with cookies turned off, you'll either have a dreadful experience or the site will just tell you to turn on cookies or go annoy its competition :-) Or for that matter, Mark Nottingham's employer wouldn't do much of its bread-and-butter business if people followed REST prescriptions and didn't maintain server-side state except in identified resources. (Isn't keeping server-side state in a programmer-friendly manner what app servers do, in a nutshell?)

So, show us the real success stories for limited verb large-scaled automated systems that do something more that deliver information for human consumption. My guess is that engineering considerations such as performance / scalability tend to weed these out, even if they could work in principle.

entry.title: re: Correcting MNot
entry.content:
Hey Mike,

Way to argue for complexity!

Seriously, I don't think that REST is the one true way, just that there's some value to identifying things that have state with universal identifiers. Please don't paint me as an extremist.

Don's previous post quoting Bill is on the money; the real lesson here is that both sides are far from perfect, and that they can learn from each other. Sorry if that isn't controversial enough.

Don,

Sorry for the delay in responding, it's been a bit of a week.

Would *love* to talk to your directory folks; can you set us up on a date? :)

Regarding Waldo; if you accept that treating remote interfaces as local ones doesn't work, I wonder why you're trying to treat local interfaces as remote ones; I think this is a false analogy.

entry.title: ABOUT / HTTP/1.2
entry.content: The discussion on the intersection between Web Services and REST continues, but a passing aside may hint at an equally imprtant issue for Web architecture.

entry.title: Coordination vs. Action verbs
entry.content:
Patrick Logan has a nice (and simple) model for thinking about verbs and messaging.
 
I completely agree with the first two paragraphs.
 
As for the last paragraph, I would argue that HTTP POST is a "coordination" verb and that WSDL is typically used for defining "action" verbs. It's not clear from Patrick's post whether we agree or disagree.
 
To pour gasoline on this particular fire, had WS-Whatever contained a "POST" or "ENQUEUE" operation, then we'd have had a nice little recursive bootstrap (especially if you tunneled SOAP envelopes as SOAP payloads).
 
Here's a nice little example to end the evening with:
 
POST /target.svc HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/soap+xml
 
<S:Envelope xmlns:wsa="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing" xmlns:S="http://www.w3.org/2004/05/soap-envelope/">
  <S:Header>
    <wsa:Action>http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/09/coordination/Enqueue</wsa:Action>
    <wsa:To>uri-for-coordinator</wsa:To>
  </S:Header>
  <S:Body>
    <S:Envelope>
      <S:Header>
        <wsa:Action>http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/transfer/Delete</wsa:Action>
        <wsa:To>uri-for-actor</wsa:To>
      </S:Header>
      <S:Body/>
    </S:Envelope>
  </S:Body>
</S:Envelope>
 
Lest anyone have the wrong reaction, (a) yes, we've thought about doing such things in building 42 and (b) no we don't intend on doing this kind of thing (at least not in any externally visible manner).
 
BTW, Patrick, I hope you'll be at the SellsCon next week.

entry.title: Behavior Definition
Change in Plans for XML DevCon
entry.content:
I hate having to provide titles and abstracts months in advance of an event.
 
Thankfully, I have pictures of the chair of the XML DevCon naked, so he lets me change topics midstream.
 
Here's the title and abstract for next week's talk by yours truly.
 
WS-Why?
 
This talk will make sense of why various WS-* specs came to life and which ones every developer should ignore. Naturally, the size of this set is non-zero, however, it is not the entire universe. Hopefully, the audience will be left with a mental model for what to ignore going forward as the WS-* machine continues to move forward.

entry.title: Tim Bray on SellsCon
entry.content:
Tim has a very nice post-mortem on last week's SellsCon.
 
Tim calls out that the perceived dependency on XSD hasn't helped community adoption. The problem here is with perception as much as with practice. There are any number of ways to use our current platform (ASMX) without relying on XSD, and the same will be true for Indigo. Moreover, it's not by accident that we spec the WS-* using "exemplar-style" pseudo-schemas and provide XSD as non-normative backup.
 
A related (and interesting) thought experiment is to build a WSDL importer that ignored the wsdl:types/xs:schema element and just provided XmlReader or XmlElement support.  If you assume doc/lit, you could probably get away from processing the binding as well (especially now that WS-Addressing spec'ed how to put Action URI in portTypes where they belong).

entry.title: re: Tim Bray on SellsCon
entry.content:
Hallelujah! I thought it was just me who's been thinking that WSDL doesn't really add any value when:

1) you're not bothered about XSD and ORM - ie you'll do the message processing yourself
2) you need a more dynamic/flexible binding mechanism than WSDL gives you

I'm glad to hear that Indigo won't be mandating using stuff that we don't always need. Will it make it equally easy NOT to use it though? - because asmx doesn't. WSDL seems to have gained most traction in the codegen'd proxy space with tooling but as we all heard (and agreed?) at the SellsCon last week, that experience isn't always great if constrained by XSD.

entry.title: WSDL a la dynamic
entry.content: I have done exactly this in Super Dynamic Invoker. You can access wsdl/types as XmlElement (my own API not .NET ...) and then if you prefer cast XsSchema view (use to dig sequence of elements for doc/literal bindings) or not - your choice ;-)

entry.title: re: Tim Bray on SellsCon
entry.content: I'm glad to hear that Indigo

entry.title: OOPSLA
entry.content:
I'm spending the day in Vancouver at OOPSLA.
 
AndersH and I sat on a Republican vs. Democrat panel that Martin Fowler was moderating. With a couple of exceptions, it was pretty good natured.
 
My favorite moment was Alan Knight's comment that dynamic languages allow you to program half formed thoughts. I couldn't resist point out that Microsoft has been accused of routinely shipping half formed thoughts and that we've been able to do it just fine using statically typed languages.
 
It was fun meeting John Crupi, especially after being so influenced by his book's implications.
 
Finally, it was striking how folks at this conference are really true believers. The ORM folks seem pretty committed. The dynamic language folks seem pretty committed. The IoC folks seem pretty sure that the AOP folks should be committed.

entry.title: re: OOPSLA
entry.content:
Who was the Republican and who was the Democrat? ;)

I'd just like to say how great it is that your blog now has comments (as opposed to the one back at GDN). You're truly an asset to the community and any method that allows interaction between those of us who breathe smaller quantities of nerd gas and you is truly wonderful.

entry.title: Dress Codes
entry.content:
This dress code description from Burleson Consulting is amazing.
 
It reminds me of the dress code that my ex-partner instituted at my previous company.
 
All instructors must wear long pants.
 
When I asked why we needed such a dress code, he explained that if an instructor couldn't handle the technical grilling that students often dish out, that the long pants would make a difference.
 
I'll be interested to see if Keith, Aaron, or Fritz bring their short pants to the Pluralsight gig this week.

entry.title: re: Dress Codes
entry.content:
As a former MCT, I can't even begin to describe how hilarious the statement, "if an instructor couldn't handle the technical grilling that students often dish out, that the long pants would make a difference" is to me. I haven't attended many ILT courses because...well, most of them suck quite frankly, and that opinion will not be swayed one way or the other due to how well the instructor was dressed. A well dressed idiot is still an idiot. I've met very well dressed instructors, and that was their only good quality (if that even counts, which it doesn't). For years, I had it in my mind that I would NEVER pay for ILT training until a certain badass instructor named Jason Masterman taught one at the Microsoft building in downtown Phoenix (I attended for free). After that I signed up for Guerilla .NET (which I paid for out of pocket BTW). Had Mike Woodring or Keith Brown been terrible instructors, wearing pants wouldn't have cut it for me as a customer. I would have been severely pissed. The fact is: if Masterman, Brown, or Woodring are teaching a course that I'm interested in taking (and have the $ for), they can teach in tight rubber shorts shorts for all I care, and I will still attend. The point: forget the pants policy, worry about having the best instructors. Just my $.02.

PS. Please don't tell those guys to wear tight rubber shorts. :-)

entry.title: re: More on J2EE
entry.content:
Its too any to blame OSS projects for fragmenting the grand revenue stream that was J2EE.

But we have always had fragmentation before OSS. EJB? did you mean on websphere, weblogic or Sun's impl. XML parser? Crimson, Xerces, or something else? And yes, such fragmentation is problematic, which is why projects lock down their versions. Both Ant and Axis insist on Xerces, for example. Well, maybe insist is too strong, but happyaxis.jsp tells you off for using crimson.

What Jboss and geronimo are doing is reducing the cost of classic EJB to the same cost as the alternatives, so we will see what people choose now. Futhermore, leading edge OSS projects are shaping the commercial products. Hibernate is feeding into EJB3, and of course Ant is the spritual grandfather of MSBuild...

entry.title: GET vs. REST
entry.content:
I love Dave Orchard's missives on the "sweet spot" which as most people have concluded, is a uniform GET + ad hoc operations/verbs.
 
I've been working with the Indigo management infrastructure team and this is precisely where we landed when it came to remote management of the Indigo runtime. We implement WS-Transfer's GET and WS-Enumeration's ENUMERATE operations pretty much everywhere, but beyond that, it's 100% domain-specific operations (e.g., Transaction.Abort, AppDomain.Unload, Service.Stop, etc).
 
It's not an accident that this is precisely how the web actually works too. Uniform GET + ad hoc operations in the form of POST.

entry.title: re: GET vs. REST
entry.content: Hey Don. It's cool to see GET receiving some well deserved love, but you're incorrect when you say that the Web works using ad-hoc operations via POST. The *vast* majority of the uses of POST work simply by submitting a document to a document processing resource/service, where POST *is* the only operation. There are no ad-hoc, service-specific operations in those cases.

entry.title: D70
entry.content:
After spending time with Bill Williams' D100 this week, I decided to bite the bullet and buy a Nikon D70.  I lost several hours this morning contemplating the Canon EOS 20D vs. Nikon D70 issue, but eventually was pushed over the edge by the faster flash sync speed of the D70.
 
The shooting experience is fantastic - I haven't spent enough time looking at the results to gauge whether it's good enough to shelve the analog SLR, but my guess is we're done with 35mm for good.

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content:
I just bought the Canon Digital Rebel and with the Hitachi 4gb microdrive, have over 1000 pictures that can be taken at the large jpeg setting.

You get lazy at first. Instead of picking good shots, you just fire the thing in every direction. Then you get tired of deleting 87 of 91 shots and realize that you have to be just as careful taking a shot with a digital SLR as a regular SLR (or any other film camera).

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content:
I've had mine since July. It's my third SLR and first digital SLR. Love it!

One unexpected complexity is the post-processing. I'm spending the day with Photoshop and 100 pics from Italy (culled from 400). PS might actually be deeper than the Platform SDK. Man, what a learning curve.

But the instant feedback digital gives you and the control of the SLR has made photography even more enjoyable.

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content: Don, you can sync 20D with newer flashes at 1/4000 sec. See http://photonotes.org/articles/eos-flash/#fp.

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content:
I bought a Canon 10D in Summer 2003. I have over 10Gb of photos since then. :-) The trouble I find is in indexing the photos, and my wife complains that she nevers sees photos any more (cos I'm always on the PC), and I never print them out.

That's the only drawback with digital is that I don't tend to print as many photos. I have a photo printer, and loads of paper, ink, I also have a VERY efficient online photo printer (www.photobox.co.uk), but don't bother to use it either. Oh well, the other benefits of digital do outweight the few drawbacks.

The other thing is, I will have to upgrade my camera every few years. My last analog SLR was a Canon EOS 100 which I bought in 1991, and it served me well all the way up to 2003. I doubt I will still be using my 10D in 12 years time.

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content:
> we're done with 35mm for good.

I'm sure. Analog film will go the way of unmanaged code...

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content:
The one thing that will send you back is shutter lag, if you take shots where that is important (shooting RAW also occasionally will get you waiting intolerably). Every once in a while it drives me nuts, but the digital advantages are overwhelming.
The biggest problem is that I am trying to consider ways to justify a d2X, some DX lenses, perhaps that new digital back Mamiya or Hassleblad. It gets addicting...
The future looks very good for digital photography.

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content:
I like the camera, but two things will keep you wanting something more and different in form factor, just like your laptop struggle.

First, if you're used to an EOS-1 or F5 (or the digital equivalents), the viewfinder of the D70 is way too small to 'micro compose' as Sam Abbel put it the other night. Those big cameras let you see people's eyes. Non-SLR cameras have a nifty little swivel LCD for that 'ground glass' kind of focusing you might like from a Hasselblad. However, smaller cameras can't compare to the analog feel of the viewfinders on the big SLR's or med format ground glass.

Second, the kit lens has enough barrel distortion at the wide end to be noticeable, and yet the lens is big enough that you'll feel a little robbed since the guy next to you with the little CoolPix 8400 can go wider than you and it fits in his jacket.

Overall, congrats for making the leap. Keep a little 'diary' camera in your pocket and this in trunk. It allows one to make beautiful photos. Then all you need is all that time you haven't got.

--> Mike

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content:
Congratulations! I bought mine last April, and couldn't be happier. Funny thing, however. I also bought a Nikon N80 Film camera, and have been doing a lot of Black & White film as well. I use the D70 for everyday family, events, etc. shots and I use film when I want to be artsy-fartsy. I even dusted off the developing tanks.

The only problem is all my spare cash now goes into more lenses, flash, etc.

entry.title: re: D70
entry.content:
Have had D70 since march 04 and I agree it is a joy to work/play with. Of course, there will alway be a "better" camera out there, and for a while D70 was exactly that (i'm counting the pro models D1H and alike out of this argument). Now, the Canon 20D seems to have taken over that status, but instead of whining about "Don, you should have gotten this or that", I say "have a ball". It is more than good enough for non-professional photographer and just buying the better model won't make you any better a photographer.

May I suggest a good macro lens, like Nikon 105mm macro (you will stick to Nikon lenses I hope, such a good camera deserves no less. Forget about Sigma (I hear it stands for Significant Malfunction), Tokina and other crap)

Fairly easy to do, I've got the energy blue theme running on my regular desktop.

C:\WINDOWS\Resources\Themes\Royale\Wallpaper\energybliss.jpg

entry.content:
I'm looking to switch brands for my next laptop - the T41P I'm typing this on is probably my last IBM machine.
 
I'd love to get a Sony, but the right form factors have limited hardware (I need at least 1.5G of ram given my Virtual PC addiction).
 
The last time I suggested buying a Powerbook, several people privately informed me that VPC performance would be very disappointing given the kind of stuff I do.
 
Ideally, I'd buy a non-Toshiba Tablet PC with 1.5-2GB of RAM, but I don't know of such a beast. I can't stand Toshiba keyboards, even though I rarely use the ~ key now that I've stopped programming in C++.
 
Ignoring the Tablet PC factor, the Dell Lattitude D400 seems close in terms of size/weight/performance, but I'm much more interested in the Alienware Sentia. I love Alienware's flexibility with respect to configuration - not to mention the fact that a max'ed out Sentia (2Ghz, 2GB ram, 100GB HD) is almost $800 less than 2Ghz/2GB/60GB Dell.
 
Any Alienware horror stories out there?

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: Mind you Don, at 5400rpm that 100Gb HD is not fast - you'll definitely notice the hit when running VPCs. Thats one of the reasons why I went for the Dell Precision M60 - you get a 7200rpm 60Gb HD. I do hear rumours that a 7200rpm 100Gb HD is on its way soon though

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: I did a lot of Dell equipment, but now switched to Acer. Top notch performance, especially since I'm hooked on VPC as well. Only drawback: 8kg weight.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: Hmmm ... why do you plan to switch away from IBM? Any horror stories? [Just asking because I try to convert most people *to* IBM these days ;-)]

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
No tablet PC? Scoble will have a heart attack.

I've always found Sonys to be too fragile for real work, after carrying it about for a month something will break, usually the screen and that's expensive. For me, I buy Toshibas :)

However work gave me a Dell D800, which is nice, except for the wide screen. Windows doesn't play well once it gets above 96DPI. System dialogs aren't resized, so text or buttons go missing and IE's default scaling of graphics is pants.

I did point the mother in law to the D400s, and she seems happy enough (once I reconfigured it so she was no longer administrator and culled the 100+ spyware executables off it). When I'm using it I find it too small, too light. It's hard to feel as if the keys are feeding back. If keyboards are your objection to buying Toshiba then you may well loathe the Dell. Also remember that if you want the full 100Gb that's two drives, so you'll be without the DVD/CD when using the second drive.

Finally, if you're using wireless and WPA-PSK both Dell and Toshiba cards have big problems dropping connections in under 5 minutes if your card is not using the Intel chipset. A registry hack fixes this, which I detailed at http://idunno.org/displayBlog.aspx/2004110601

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
Hmm, I'm looking for a laptop but I want a super hi res screen, lots of hard disk, loads of RAM. And needs to be quite rugged as I drag it around with me every day, and also as light as a feather.

What's the best machine given those requirements?

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: I too am interested in why this might be your last thinkpad. I am a loyal thinkpad owner, who also tries to switch the people around me. I find the quality far better then dell, sony, or toshiba, and the performance is usually also top notch (minus no "monster" offering like the XPS that I am aware of). Maybe it is just that fact that is enough to move you, but I drool over the specs on a T42P.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: Alienware makes excellent machines. Had I not gotten such a steal on this Inspiron XPS, my next laptop would've definitely come from a botique dealer like Alienware.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: i'm a happy thinkpad x23 user, so my usual recommendation of the x series won't do much good here, but i find they're excellent machines. i have an ex-colleague, however, who's been selling me on the virtues of alienware so i suspect you can't go too far wrong there. one other far out suggestion? moondoggie. if they're not vaporware - and at this point i'm inclined to think they are - they look cool.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: I'm using an MPC TransPort T2200 w/ 2 gigs of ram and an 60gb drive. Performace is good.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: although my spelling is awful.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
I'm a happy Area51m user here. :) This machine runs VPC just fine..and CounterStrike Source if you really want to game. ;)

I wouldn't get that 100gb hdd if I were you though. I'd stick with the faster 60gb drive.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
I've owned and used from work several Dell's, (Expiron and Latitude) and they have performed extremely well. I had a Sony at another job and the screen-size was awesome, but it _was_ brittle as someone else mentioned.

I would go with the Dell. I have had excellent results for over 4 years now.

entry.title: Dell laptop
entry.content: I just purchased a Dell Inspiron 8600. It's the fastest laptop I've used, I think because I made sure to get the 7200 RPM 60 gig drive. Every laptop I've used has always felt sluggish, even when they had near identical stats to a desktop. The only difference I could find was the HD speed.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
Go with the Toshiba tablet. I have the M200 with 2GB RAM, 2GHz Dotham M chip, 60GB hard disk (7200 RPM). *Very* nice, *very* fast. VPCs fly on it.

You can get used to the Toshiba keyboard - just like you have gotten used to the VS editor. ;)

entry.title: RE: Laptops
entry.content:
I have always been more than happy with my Sager. Performance/Configuration tends to be very close to Alienware, but at a considerably lower price. At the time I bought my NP5660, it was identical to the Area 51m (both even used identical chassis), but the Sager was nearly $1,000 cheaper.

http://www.sagernotebook.com/index.html

The only downside is that when you go for the max performance hardware, the weight and battery life can become troublesome (like with any laptop manufacturer).

Regarding running VPC... I actually run VMWare, but I find it performs better when I attach a 7200rpm external firewire drive and store my virtual machines there. Plus there is the handy side-effect that my VMs are instantly portable between laptop and desktop.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: Don Box stopped programming in C++? So the revolution is official then. ;-)

It's completely unsupported. On top of that the drivers for their cards have got memory leaks and their support is rubbish.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: As a developer I need not only a power laptop but also one that can drive two monitors. The only one I could find two years ago that did that is the one I am typing this on: Dell Precision M60. It can do its own and one external one OR with the help of D/Dock it can drive two *external* monitors (once docked). Its specs are still very impressive today. [TIP: Choose customise on dell's site to see full options]

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: When buying a laptop, I'd strongly advise you look at the vendors support history., ie. how often do they update their drivers, is their support site easy to use and updated with the latest drivers for all their machines. I've had experience with Acer being rather poor on this front with regards to their Ferarri 3200 laptop. So my advise is always check out the support site of the laptop vendor before committing to a machine.

entry.content: why the switch from thinkpad - I've got a new T42P - it's easily the best machine I've used, and that includes two sonys and a compaq mobile workstation.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:

While the Alienware laptops seem amazing, I have seen a good number of negative reviews, particularly about the quality of work, and the lack of technical support to scare me from buying one for a while. entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
I just purchased an inspiron 600M which was about $300 less than the D600 (and has 64MB video vs 32MB).

Probably not an apples to apples comparison since I am sure the lattitudes have better support, but I doubt I will use the machine for 3 years.

As is always the case with dells, don't buy the Ram from dell. Get it configured with as little as possible then hop over to Crucial.com. 1 gig of ram (single chip) for the 600M is $350.

I went with the same concept and order the cheapest harddrive from Dell and then purchased a Hitatchi 60 gig 7200 RPM HD. Ironically, Dell had the best price for the drive. :)

-Scott

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: Dell's don't hold up. Had an Inspiron 8100 that had tons 'o issues particularly with flaky wireless support. Bought a Toshiba M35-S201 in April. Best dang laptop ever owned. Found it very helpful on rides on the train every morning to do work including writing code. Battery also holds up well. No issues since I bought it. Boss liked it so much, he went out an bought same model. Picked mine up from Circuit City for about $1600.

When I was looking Dell was too expensive and I've been disapointed with their quality, Alienware was too expensive. Sager was perfectly priced with great performance.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: There is such a beast as a Non-Trashiba, tablet PC that can have RAM you need. The Motion M1400 can have up to 2GB (the centrino versions). Of course, it is a slate, but with the bluetooth you could use whatever keyboard you want.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content: I got an HP zx5000 last year after my Sony bit it. P4 3.2HT, 1 Gb RAM 80 gb 7200 HD, 15.4" monitor 1920x1200. Love it....built-in bluetooth and a/b/g wireless work great...wouldn't trade the screen for anything....only down side is I would call it a luggable, built like a tank...I take it everywhere everyday. VPCs on external USB 2 or firewire drive work nicely.

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
Yeah, I'm with many others - go with the smaller 7200 RPM drive. My 5400 HD died one day so I upgraded it to a 7200, and it felt like a totally new machine.

As far as Alienware goes, gamer magazines last year gave it top marks as far as mobile gaming goes. The negatives were simply their weight. Otherwise, I have a few friends that have them, and swear by them. So, YMMV.


-Jason

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
It's incredible what a little marketing hype will do to some people! Anyone remember RIMM memory? This RAM was pushed by Intel as the next best greatest thing since sliced bread, but at practically twice the cost of regular DIMM RAM! Seems like Intel has once again managed to convince some that a 1.5 - 2Ghz processor that uses less power is somehow equivalent to a 2.5 - 3Ghz processor! All I can say is... don't be fooled!
As for Sony products... In my opinion, over the last several years they have become a company where profits and bottom-line mean far more than quality and reliability! I have returned --and will never use again-- several Sony products including: cell phones, cordless phones, CRT monitors (both at home and in my college lab (15 CPG500 monitors)), mini-disks, etc, etc! I hate to say this about a once fine company, but Sony products are of poor reliability these days!
As for Dell... All I can say is my college issued Inspiron 8200 has had the hard drive replaced twice and the motherboard replaced 3 times! If you buy Dell, please factor into the total price, the 3 year extended warranty because you're going to need it! The best advice I have for anyone is: to do a little research into buying quality, reliable components and assembling the hardware yourself! This is even an option for laptops! www.pugetsystems.com
Good Luck all!

Has anyone else had a simialr bad experiece? If so please email me at trashiba@hotamil.co.uk

I now have a packard bell easynote which serves my purposes and works like its meant to!

entry.title: re: Laptops
entry.content:
Have you guys considered Panasonic Toughbooks?

By far the best notebooks I've ever used.

I've used and personally owned, IBMs, Toshibas, Compaqs, Dells, Sagers, and of course Panasonic. My last 6 laptops were Pans.

Panasonic also makes a reliable semi-ruggedized tablet as well.

Panasonic comes with the 3 year support and they are very good with support.

Of all the computers, the only times I had problems was installing Win2k and wiped out the BIOS based hibernation partition.

With the exception of maybe the IBMs, I think anyone who uses a Panasonic, even for a short time will be a new Convert.

The US military, local Police, and Government Utilities can't be all wrong! (Despite whether or not you agree with their politics).

-=A

entry.title: Searchin for AW Information
entry.content: Hey I have been looking for Alienware Info for a couple months now and I have seen probably everything there is to see. I really wanted an Alienware I like the looks I like the weight that the name carries. Face it Alienware is well known. A lot of people wont buy one because they cost a little more (Sometimes) depending on what you want. I want something nice as a gift for me. After everything I have seen as far as information on the web I am getting the Alienware. I just had to stop back here because that Link helped me out A LOT. [url]www.notebookforums.com[/url]. After visiting that site and watching complaints of other owners and also seeing how many trolls they get in that forum I absolutely believe that At Least half of internet complaints against Alienware are FAKE. Its not so obvious whenyou are reading an exagerated complaint about Alienware but its funny how almost none of them look real after you see the complaints that are basically verified by that forum mods and other members AND they are followed up by Alienware Tech Support. I'm no kiss ass though. If I have any problems Im gonna let people know about it. Im not rich kid I have a family and too many bills to be messing around with computer problems. Hope I remember to update this. :)

entry.title: Visual Studio 2005 as a WSDL Editor
entry.content:
While spelunking around in VS 2005, I found an amazingly cool Code Snippet - the "Code Snippet" snippet (found at C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio 8\xml\1033\expansions\snippet.xml on my box).
 
In addition to this nice "meta-snippet," Chris Lovett and the gang have included a boatload of XML Schema snippets to reduce the tedium of defining things like this:
 
            <xs:complexType name="name">
                <xs:simpleContent>
                    <xs:extension base="xs:string">
                        <xs:attribute name="attName"></xs:attribute>
                    </xs:extension>
                </xs:simpleContent>
            </xs:complexType>
Between the two of these finds, I was overcome by the urge to create a corresponding set of snippets for creating and editing WSDL/1.1 files.
 
I've uploaded the first pass of my WSDL/1.1 snippets at http://www.pluralsight.com/dbox/wsdlsnippets.zip
 
Comments/flames welcome (hey, my blog has comments!).

It make me remember the OLE2 days...

I won't write it again (ok I can), but in France & UK, people have problem when they write software using java. They are (most of the developers) thinking about having fun prior to anything so I let you imagine the whole picture and the end of a project. There are so much confusions and so much various non-unified technologies and framework, that If you take a small developer (young 30 year fresh looking well IT dev) and you tell him to act as a member of a java team using the whole picture (Tiers, Db, DNA-like, etc), the little dev man is lost.
They used to read specifications and the even don't look in deep of the implementation of some partcilar but essentials part. The problem is that they do not have O.S infrastructure under.
It's the problem.
Look at those poor MVS framework they have.
Look at the poor threading models they use.
It's a shame.

When you have people of the O.S in your back, you think twice before writting a small bad stuff with eawy cpu cycle...

I know, I'm a has-been but, I meet a lot of people sharing this vision.

J2EE like technologies will face the same OLE2 problems.
It looks good. It is good. But only when made by they own creators.

Christophe
